docs.lead_paragraph: Viagra, the Pfizer Inc. pill for correcting male impotence, smashed all records in its first three months, according to I.M.S. Health, an industry consultant, which released numbers yesterday. I.M.S. also predicted that sales of Viagra would reach $1 billion in the United States by March 1999.

headline.main: A Record Pace For Viagra Sales

docs.abstract: IMS Health says prescriptions for Pfizer Inc's Viagra, drug to correct male impotence, totaled 2.9 million between April and June, enough for estimated sales of record $259.5 million; predicts United States sales will reach $1 billion in full year (S)
docs.snippet: Viagra, the Pfizer Inc. pill for correcting male impotence, smashed all records in its first three months, according to I.M.S. Health, an industry consultant, which released numbers yesterday.     I.M.S. also predicted that sales of Viagra would...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will punish health insurance companies that deny coverage to sick people, in violation of a 1996 law, by excluding them from the lucrative insurance market for Federal employees, Administration officials said today. The law was intended to make insurance more readily available to millions of Americans who change or lose their jobs. But Federal and state officials said they saw worrisome signs that some health insurance companies were circumventing the law. They said some companies had discouraged sales to eligible individuals, charged very high premiums or penalized insurance agents selling coverage to customers with pre-existing medical problems.

headline.main: CLINTON TO PUNISH INSURERS WHO DENY HEALTH COVERAGE

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will bar health insurers that illegally deny coverage to sick people from having a share of lucrative insurance market for Federal employees; orders Office of Personnel Management, which negotiates health benefits for Federal employees and dependents, to use its purchasing power to insure that health plans comply with 1996 Kassebaum-Kennedy law, which guarantees that people losing group health insurance will have access to coverage in individual insurance market, regardless of pre-existing medical problems; law generally provides for uninterrupted coverage for people moving from one insured workplace to another; Federal employees program is nation's largest employee-sponsored health insurance program, covering nine million people through 350 health plans (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton will punish health insurance companies that deny coverage to sick people, in violation of a 1996 law, by excluding them from the lucrative insurance market for Federal employees, Administration officials said today.    The law was...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Clinton to Visit Russia Despite Arms Treaty Delay The White House said that President Clinton would travel to Russia in early September to meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin, even though the Russian legislature had not fulfilled a request to ratify the Start-2 arms control treaty. A6 The PRI Gains in Mexico Mexico's governing party, the PRI, which had seemed in retreat before a rising opposition tide, elected a former businessman to the governorship of Chihuahua, recovering a state controlled by rivals for the first time. A4

docs.lead_paragraph: Few alarm bells rang here a year ago this weekend, when Thailand's currency melted down. ''There were no crisis meetings,'' recalled Daniel K. Tarullo, President Clinton's top international economic adviser until a few months ago, ''and certainly no sense that this was the start of an economic crisis that might roll around the world.''

headline.main: After a Year, No Letup in Asia's Economic Crisis

docs.abstract: Year-old Asian economic crisis is growing more intense, instead of abating as many had hoped, and stands as largest single threat to six-year economic boom in US; while effects on most Americans have been remote, factories are beginning to slow, exports are beginning to pile up and some members of Congress are calling for swift action; from White House to International Monetary Fund, officials are concerned that effects of crisis will be worse and longer-lasting than first thought; what particularly scares Clinton Administration officials is that unpredictable economic contagion is no longer limited to Pacific Rim (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Mark R. Goldstein, M.D. (letter, July 1) emphasized that insurers are responsible for escalating health costs because they pressure doctors to see more patients, forcing them to rely on expensive technology to make diagnoses instead of listening to them.

headline.main: Medical Savings Plan Is Boon to Uninsured; Don't Blame Insurers

docs.abstract: Dr Edward J Volpintesta letter, responding to July 1 Dr Mark R Goldstein letter, says overuse of medical technology, not health insurance companies, is responsible for rising health costs

docs.lead_paragraph: Citing losses and cuts in Government payments, the nation's biggest health maintenance organizations are quitting managed care programs for the poor and elderly. Their retreat is most pronounced in Medicaid programs. Health care analysts warn of a reversal of Government progress this decade in steering the poor into the mainstream of the health care system, both to provide good care and hold down costs.

headline.main: LARGEST H.M.O.'S CUTTING THE POOR AND THE ELDERLY

docs.abstract: Nation's biggest health maintenance orgainzations are quitting managed care programs for poor and elderly, citing losses and cuts in Government payments; organizations such as Aetna US Healthcare, Pacificare, Oxford Health Plans, Kaiser Permanents and Blue Cross and Blue Shield Assns have shut down Medicaid services in at least 12 states, including New York, New Jersey, Florida, Massachussetts and Connecticut; withdrawals have spread to Medicare-managed programs for elderly, primarily in rural communities with few patients and where clinics and doctors are scarce; in other states, HMO's run by companies are reducing services to Medicare patients and charging for care that had been fully covered; health care analysts warn of reversal of Government progress over past decade in steering poor into mainstream health care system, both in providing good care and holding down costs; patient advocates say they fear retreat will mean return to crowded 'Medicaidmill' clinics delivering inferior care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Warming Up to Patients' Rights'' (editorial, June 29) was wrong about what constitutes a ''poison pill'' in the proposed legislation on unfair practices by health maintenance organizations. You claim medical savings accounts are ''anathema'' to the Democrats and the White House, yet the Democrats have supported the accounts for some time.

docs.lead_paragraph: DOCTORS and nurses moved from case to case with practiced ease. Antibiotic flowed from an intravenous drip, destroying the deadly bacteria that threatened Barney's life. Pischa lay hooked up to a heart monitor. Emergency surgery was needed to save Fozzy, who was brought in with a malignant tumor on the inside of her mouth.

headline.main: CAT Scans for Dogs, Chemotherapy for Cats

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In New Jersey, a person is killed in an auto accident every 10 hours and 42 minutes. Injuries from car crashes occur every four minutes. These tragic numbers can be lowered through increased use of seat belts.

headline.main: Seat Belt Laws Should Be More Effective

docs.abstract: New Jersey Assemblyman Herbert C Conaway Jr letter says he is co-sponsoring legislation that would make noncompliance with seat belt laws primary offense (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    In New Jersey, a person is killed in an auto accident every 10 hours and 42 minutes. Injuries from car crashes occur every four minutes. These tragic numbers can be lowered through increased use of seat belts.
